source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk6
evidence_span: The Hanford N Reactor contains 1004 cold-worked Zircaloy-2 pressure tubes made by four different fabrication routes.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk6
evidence_span: They operate at 395 to $5 6 0 \textdegree$ (475 to $5 6 6 \ \mathbf { K } )$ with a hoop stress of 8400 psi $( 5 8 \bf { M P a } )$ and a peak neutron flux of $2 . 2 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 3 }$ neutrons $( \mathbf { n } ) / \mathbf { c m } ^ { 2 } / \mathbf { \bar { s } }$ (>1 MeV).

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk6

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk6
evidence_span: Length measurements on all the tubes after $5 0 0 0 0 \textbf { h }$ of operation show elongation up to 0.4 percent in proportion to channel power.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: The highest average elongation (0.35 percent) is observed in tubes fabricated with a high extrusion ratio (29:1) and a high amount of cold work (30 percent)

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: The lowest elongation (0.19 percent) is observed in tubes fabricated with a lower extrusion ratio (13:1) and a lower amount of cold work (17.5 percent)

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: Intermediate elongations (0.26 percent) are observed in tubes fabricated with a high extrusion ratio (29:1) and low cold work (17.5 percent)

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: Intermediate elongations (0.26 percent) are observed in tubes fabricated with a low extrusion ratio (8:1) and high cold work (30 to 35 percent)

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: The elongations and diameter changes are analyzed in terms of two separate components: a stress independent component, irradiation growth, and a stress dependent component, irradiation creep

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: The magnitudes and signs of the two components depend on texture, dislocation density (cold work), and neutron flux

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: creep is enhanced by the presence of fast (>1 MeV) neutrons

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: these alloys change dimensions, or "grow," as the result of fast neutron irradiation even though external stress is absent
